text:
SIMONA ONORI: We have reached a
crossroads with transportation.

The way we move around today
is simply not sustainable.

Climate change is an
ever-growing threat,

and reducing emissions
from vehicles
is a critical step we must take.

Transportation is now
the largest contributor
to greenhouse gas emissions.

According to a recent
study by the EPA,

transportation has overtaken
the electric power generation
sector.

Over 90% of the fuel used
in transportation in the US
is petroleum based.

Electrification of the
transportation sector

has the potential to achieve
US decarbonization goals

once renewable power
generation reaches
higher levels nationwide.

Engineers have developed many
state of the art propulsion

technologies and the
battery electric vehicles

and hybrid electric vehicles
are the ones with the most
decarbonization potential.

Lithium ion battery
technology has

revolutionized the automotive
industry in the past decade.

A surge in lithium
ion battery production

has led to 85% decline
in price, making

electra vehicles
and energy storage

commercially viable for
the first time in history.

Lithium ion batteries
hold the potential

to transition away from
fossil fuel dependence

and are set to play a much
greater role in the coming
decade.

The aim of this course
is to introduce you

to the hybrid and electric
vehicle technologies,

and understand their
potential to reduce greenhouse

gases while discussing the
main technological aspects
of such advanced powertrains.

We will talk about
electric Motors

and compare key
technologies available

This course is for anyone
interested in gaining

the knowledge and
competence in vehicle

components in their integration,
energy management, energy

conversion and storage devices,
and battery management system

design, and fast
charging technologies.

I'm Simona Onori, Assistant
Professor of Energy Resources
Engineering, here at Stanford.
Let's do this together.
